channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-16891] Try copying to the Netty ByteBuf directly from the WALEdit
item.description:
-> The FanOutOneBlockAsyncDFSOutput is a much sophisticated dfs client model that works with Netty ByteBuf. Here we hold on connection to the datanodes using
Netty Channels. And the idea is to write data direclty to these channels.
AsyncHLog gets an append call. The AysncWAL uses the HBase's ByteArrayOutputSTream and so the content of the cell is written to this BAOS and that is again
copied to the netty Bytebuf in the FanOutOneBlockAsyncDFSOutput.
So when the sync call happens this FanoutDFSoutput does the checksum calcualtion itself and then writes the content of this buffer direclty to the DN channel.

-> In case of FSHLOg this is different. When an append call comes we direclty write the content to the FSDataOutputStream (it is copied to this stream).
Then here internally there is a checkSum calculation that happens. when a sync call happens there is noth ing to do except to notify the NN to flush the latest
data.

AS we can see from the above that there are two copies in AsyncWAL

-> From the Cell to the BAOS
-> From the BAOS to the Netty byte buf
-> On sync() call, do check sum and finally flush the netty byte buf to the DN channel

In case of FSHLog
-> From cell to the FSDataoutputstream. data is copied. Check sum happens here.
-> Sync call just tries to notify the NN.
item.summary: Try copying to the Netty ByteBuf directly from the WALEdit

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: We doing native checksumming in both places?
Both are doing PureJava32CRC type of checksumming.

The hack that I tried here. Just pasting the snippet. I am already working on a full fledged patch\
In AsyncProtobufWriter#append


    length.addAndGet(buf.size());

    output.write(buf.getBuffer(), 0, buf.size());

    buf.reset();

      for (Cell cell : entry.getEdit().getCells()) {

        length.addAndGet(((KeyValue)cell).getLength());

        output.write(((KeyValue)cell).getBuffer(), ((KeyValue)cell).getOffset(), ((KeyValue)cell).getLength());

      }

And inside the Asyncoutput write I tried writing the length and the data together at one shot.
Something like this


buf.ensureWritable(len + Bytes.SIZEOF_INT);

    if (cryptoCodec == null) {

      buf.writeInt(len);

      buf.writeBytes(b, off, len);

    } else {

      ByteBuffer inBuffer = ByteBuffer.wrap(b, off, len);

      cryptoCodec.encrypt(inBuffer, buf.nioBuffer(buf.writerIndex(), len));

      buf.writerIndex(buf.writerIndex() + len);

    }

Duo Zhang
Is it ok to convert the AsyncOutput to extend java.io,OutputStream so that we could pass the AsyncOuput instance directly to
coded.getEncoder(OutputStream os) so that we can directly copy the cell content to the AsyncOutput.
I think we'd better add new methods to the CellEncoder? The semantics are different.

If we add new methods in CellEncoder then we may have to impl them in all the CellEncoder impl and this AsyncOutput is specific to WAL. So I am not sure if it will look better.
I agree AsyncOutput has a special flush method and its purpose is little different but any way for this JIRA I need a write(int).
And for the default OutputSTream's flush() can we throw IllegalStateException?
Just parking a patch for reference. Not the final one.

Oh Codec is LimitedPrivate... And BaseEncoder is also LimitPrivate and has a public constructor which takes a OutputStream...
And there is a flush method...

OK, I give up... What about this

coded.getEncoder(new OutputStream()

{ // actually write to the AsyncFSOutput }

);
You change the semantic of void write(int b) method in OutputStream? Why?

You change the semantic of void write(int b) method in OutputStream?

You mean why I need this? Because for writing the cell i need the cell length which is an int and then the actual cell.
Or did you mean something else?

I do not think this is a good idea. You should follow the semantic of OutputStream as the you just use OutputStream as the CellEncoder's parameter, not a subclass of OutputStream. I think most implementations of OutputStream will only write a byte, not an int...

We have an OS extension mainly for writing BB. In that we have added writeInt() support also. Ya that is not a big deal. We can write as 4 bytes. The write API which takes BB is most imp for us. Just saying
Oh, now I got what you meant. Actually I read that API wrongly. write(int b) is writing a byte only. Ya I changed it to write int. My bad. Ok anyway we can write byte by byte if needed.

Use an OutputStream wrapper that writes to AsyncFSOutput directly.
ramkrishna.s.vasudevan Is this enough?

Thanks.

This looks good.
So you will be writing byte by byte for the Int case and you don't want to support the copy at once way? Because every time you write a byte 


if (eventLoop.inEventLoop()) {

you check for the above and also do 


  buf.ensureWritable(len);

If we could write the entire thing at one shot all this can be done only once per cell.
Also we would like to support this for ByteBuffers also. So it would be better if we could add that support for which we may have to extend ByteBufferSupportOutputStream.
The good thing here is that you have ensured that every where you write to Asyncoutput (it supports writing from BB) and there is no need of that 'buf' (ByteArrayoutputStream') now?

In fact if AsyncOutput could support write(Cell, len) - if that API supports writing the length as integer followed by the bytes at one shot that would be much better


private void writeCellData(byte[] b, int offset, int len) {

    buf.ensureWritable(len + Size_ofINT);

    if (cryptoCodec == null) {

     buf.writeInt(len)

      buf.writeBytes(b, off, len);

    } else {

         // similar like above

    }

  }

The API name may not be good but this is what we ideally want. In the normal WALcellCodec case we don have these additional checks.

Good that we can avoid 2 copy now.
But the wrapper is just normal OS only.. We need to make the wrapper object implements, ByteBufferSupportOutputStream. We have write(BB) API there. So any way we can directly write DBB to AsyncOuput. Ya any way this interface will have writeInt() support as well.

Initially when the work was done, it was done as java ByteArrayOS and then as per my comment only it was changed to make hbase implemented ByteArrayOS as that supports BB based APIs. So here the new wrapper also do that, we are good.. Ya AsyncOuput also need to support BB write.

I can make the patch for that ByteBuffer support in another JIRA too Duo Zhang.But the only thing to see is that
ByteBuf.writeBytes(ByteBuffer) does not accept offset and length. So we may have to duplicate/slice every time. Which is much better than copying onheap. (though will generate garbage).

I do not know what you guys have done to the CellEncoder so I can not follow...

We just use Codec.getEncoder(OutputStream) to create an Encoder, not ByteBufferSupportOutputStream. And all the related code in the Encoder is byte array based...

U can see in EnsureKvEncoder


public void write(Cell cell) throws IOException {

      checkFlushed();

      // Make sure to write tags into WAL

      ByteBufferUtils.putInt(this.out, KeyValueUtil.getSerializedSize(cell, true));

      KeyValueUtil.oswrite(cell, this.out, true);

    }

KVUtil#oswrite


public static int oswrite(final Cell cell, final OutputStream out, final boolean withTags)

      throws IOException {

    if (cell instanceof ExtendedCell) {

      return ((ExtendedCell)cell).write(out, withTags);

    } else {

..

All our cells in server side will be ExtendedCell type.
Pls see OffheapKeyValue


public int write(OutputStream out, boolean withTags) throws IOException {

    int length = getSerializedSize(withTags);

    ByteBufferUtils.copyBufferToStream(out, this.buf, this.offset, length);

    return length;

  }

And then BBUtil


public static void copyBufferToStream(OutputStream out, ByteBuffer in,

      int offset, int length) throws IOException {

    if (out instanceof ByteBufferSupportOutputStream) {

      ((ByteBufferSupportOutputStream) out).write(in, offset, length);

    } else if (in.hasArray()) {

      out.write(in.array(), in.arrayOffset() + offset, length);

    } else {

      for (int i = 0; i < length; ++i) {

        out.write(toByte(in, offset + i));

      }

    }

  }

So ya in Encoders we have OutputSTream type only.. Here in this util there is a type check and we avoid on heap copy from DBB.

The magic lies here


 public static int oswrite(final Cell cell, final OutputStream out, final boolean withTags)

      throws IOException {

    if (cell instanceof ExtendedCell) {

      return ((ExtendedCell)cell).write(out, withTags);

    } else {

Inside ExtendedCell#write() we call BbUtil#copyBufferToStream() and there we check for


    if (out instanceof ByteBufferSupportOutputStream) {

      ((ByteBufferSupportOutputStream) out).write(in, offset, length);

So things work fine as we are copying from the BB backing the cell to the OutputStream directly.
I think we will commit this patch as is now and discuss BB support in another JIRa. That is only for offheap write path support. For now that is not there so I would say we can commit this.

Got it. Thanks.

So here we should make the OutputStreamWrapper implement ByteBufferSupportOutputStream. Let me prepare a new patch.

In patch in writeMagicAndWALHeader


output.write(ProtobufLogReader.PB_WAL_MAGIC);

You need not write that now?
Implement writeInt and writeByteBuffer.
It was removed by accident... I wanted to change it to output.write(magic). Fixed in the new patch.

LGTM. Just ensure that


private void write0(ByteBuffer bb) {

373	    int len = bb.remaining();

374	    buf.ensureWritable(len);

375	    if (cryptoCodec == null) {

376	      buf.writeBytes(bb);

377	    } else {

378	      cryptoCodec.encrypt(bb, buf.nioBuffer(buf.writerIndex(), len));

379	      buf.writerIndex(buf.writerIndex() + len);

380	    }

The buf.writeBytes(bb) does not change the position or limit of 'bb'. If it does not then fine. If not you may have to reset back.

I'm not sure but I think it will change the bb's position. But it does not matter since I will call duplicate in the upper layer. As you said, ByteBuf does not support write(bb, off, len).


    @Override

    public void write(ByteBuffer b, int off, int len) throws IOException {

      ByteBuffer bb = b.duplicate();

      bb.position(off);

      bb.limit(off + len);

      out.write(bb);

    }

But it does not matter since I will call duplicate in the upper layer.

Ya. I forgot that. Then good.

In AsyncFSOutputHelper 


 @Override

188	      public void writeInt(int i) {

189	        write(Ints.toByteArray(i));

190	      }

191	

192	      @Override

193	      public void write(ByteBuffer bb) {

194	        byte[] dst = new byte[bb.remaining()];

195	        bb.get(dst);

196	        write(dst);

197	      }

U can just create the 'out' here as org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.ByteArrayOutputStream object and then u can just delegate the call to this.out
I mean here


return new AsyncFSOutput() {



      private final ByteArrayOutputStream out = new ByteArrayOutputStream();

Else LGTM
Ya we can not avoid the BB duplicate call as netty ByteBuff do not accept any offset pos and length. It will be bit strange to accept those with a BB on which one can set position and length. We did that to avoid garbage.
This is used to make the behavior the same with FanOutOneBlockAsyncDFSOutput where we always buffer all data in memory if you do not call flush.

That is ok. I mean instead of java BAOS create hbase package BAOS so that writeBB API is available in it. U can avoid temp copy

byte[] dst = new byte[bb.remaining()];

The implementation throws IOException which will make the code a bit ugly...

Let's do it in another issue. It does not make sense to throw IOException for BAOS since it does not touch any external device, only memory operations...

-1 overall

Any concerns on the new patch? Anoop Sam John ramkrishna.s.vasudevan
Am ffine and +1 if tests pass.
Thanks. Will commit later if no other objections.

Is this a create of a Runnable per byte written? eventLoop.submit(() -> writeInt0);
Otherwise, patch looks good. Clean.
It will but it could only happen in testcase. In AsyncFSWAL we always call these methods in the event loop thread.

Pushed to master.

Thanks all for reviewing.
